key_7.snippet: LEAD:   Unlike architecture, much in interior design history is fleeting and unrecorded. In contrast to architects, decorators have not traditionally written philosophical treatises on their work -perhaps, C. Ray Smith suggests, because they've ne...
key_7.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Unlike architecture, much in interior design history is fleeting and unrecorded. In contrast to architects, decorators have not traditionally written philosophical treatises on their work -perhaps, C. Ray Smith suggests, because they've never had a philosophy. Then there is the matter of pioneering female decorators like Ruby Ross Wood who, owing to vanity, never divulged their birth dates; all this makes the historian's job trying, at best.

headline.main: Report From the Interior

key_7.snippet: The Fashion in Film Festival’s third series is a showcase of lavish and fantastical eye candy, presenting the work of costume design greats like Adrian and Edith Head....
key_7.lead_paragraph: Kicking off this weekend at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, the Fashion in Film Festival will be showing its third series of quality films, “Birds of Paradise.” Focusing primarily on the role of the costume, the festival aims to serve as a visual history lesson for fashion and film buffs with a timeline of European and American cinematic gems. Films scheduled to screen include the rare (Nino Oxilia’s “Rapsodia Satanica,” Jack Smith’s “Normal Love”) and the already loved (Cecil B. DeMille’s “Male and Female”).
key_7.abstract: The Fashion in Film Festival’s third series is a showcase of lavish and fantastical eye candy, presenting the work of costume design greats like Adrian and Edith Head.

headline.main: A Fest for the Eyes

key_9.snippet: Maybe even important artists can miss their true calling. This idea may cross the mind more than once during ''Art/Fashion,'' a sometimes wonderful, spiffily turned-out exhibition of art-related fashion and fashion-related art at the Guggenheim Mu...
key_9.lead_paragraph: Maybe even important artists can miss their true calling. This idea may cross the mind more than once during ''Art/Fashion,'' a sometimes wonderful, spiffily turned-out exhibition of art-related fashion and fashion-related art at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo. The notion registers in the show's first gallery, where a bright, dynamic vest designed by the Futurist Giacomo Balla may strike some as more appealing, in a Paul Smith sort of way, than his paintings. It pops up again in a gallery dominated by the boldly geometric clothing and designs of the painter Sonia Delaunay. It is stunning to see Delaunay transpose the ideas of modernist abstraction onto women's backs; a similar translation occurs in the emblematic, paper-doll-like fashion drawings of the Russian Constructivist Varvara Stepanova.
key_9.abstract: Roberta Smith reviews Art/Fashion, exhibition of art-related fashion and fashion-related art at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo; photo (M)

headline.main: Serious Side of an Infatuation With Fashion
